results.title: Aboriginal Education in Victoria: VAECG (A)
results.creator_credit: Vincent O'Donnell, Open Channel Productions and Melbourne State College. Media Production Centre
results.brief_description: Explains the workings of the Victorian Aboriginal Education Consultative Group. Shows how the group operates with Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people in Shepparton, Robinvale and Echuca. Introduced by Norman Lacy, Assistant Minister of Education.

results.title: Even chance (A)
results.creator_credit: Martin Zierman, Sabina Baltrukomis, Victoria. Office of the Commissioner for Equal Opportunity and Curriculum Branch, Ministry of Ed
results.brief_description: Alice, a young Aboriginal woman, leaves her home in a country town to work in the city. She finds employment but things start to go wrong and eventually she is dismissed. Alice decides to take her case to the Office of the Commissioner for Equal Opportunity. The program highlights examples of harassment, prejudice, stereotyping and discrimination.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Martin Zierman, Sabina Baltrukomis, Victoria. Office of the Commissioner for Equal Opportunity and Curriculum Branch, Ministry of Ed

results.title: The Lost time capsule
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Bennett, Heather Ogilvie, Australian Bicentennial Authority and Look At It My Way Films
results.brief_description: In the year 2088 a group of children discover a time capsule from the Bicentenary year. When opened it shows a short, musical, promotional film with the theme “Living together always”, highlighting the multicultural nature of Australian society, the outdoor life, brief film excerpts from Australia’s modern history, culminating in the creation of a mural by schoolchildren.

results.title: Aboriginal bark painting (A)
results.creator_credit: Latrobe University. School of Education. Media Centre
results.brief_description: Made in partnership with the Barinaga Aboriginal Co-operative at Maningrida, Northern Territory. Provides an informative look at the bark paintings of Arnhem Land, placing the art work firmly in the context of Aboriginal belief systems and using traditional techniques. A useful complement to “The art and craft of Maningrida”. Narrated by Robin Cuming.

results.title: Whitewashed (A)
results.creator_credit: Sue Ross and New South Wales Institute of Technology
results.brief_description: Examines the removal of Aboriginal children from their families and their placement in foster homes with white parents, the effect upon the children and the continuation of the practice in NSW today.

results.title: Warriors
results.creator_credit: Richard Guthrie, Commonwealth Dept of Aboriginal Affairs and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Rainbow serpent”.
Bob Maza and Eric Willmot, author of an unpublished novel on the exploits of Pemulwuy, who led resistance to the British colonisation of Australia, discuss the role that Pemulwuy and other Aboriginal warriors played in the early years of the British colony of Australia. Their guerrilla and confrontational tactics are contrasted with those of Bennelong, who sought some form of reconciliation. The program includes dramatised enactments of some of these events.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Guthrie, Commonwealth Dept of Aboriginal Affairs and SBS-TV

results.title: Sacred sites
results.creator_credit: Richard Guthrie, Commonwealth Dept of Aboriginal Affairs and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Rainbow serpent”.
Bob Maza narrates this exploration of the Australian Aborigine’s relationship to his sacred sites. Several sites are visited with their guardians who explain the importance of maintaining the sites and protecting them from the tourist, mining and agricultural industries. Sites visited include, Merella Cave, W.A., Uluru, Alice Springs, Guru Guru Cave, W.A. and Milbrodale, N.S.W. There are also extensive interviews with Charles Perkins.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Guthrie, Commonwealth Dept of Aboriginal Affairs and SBS-TV

results.title: Survivors (A)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Rainbow serpent”.
This program, narrated by Aboriginal playwright and actor, Bob Maza, concentrates on the attempts by the 4000 strong Tasmanian Aboriginal community to reveal that Truganini was not the last of the Tasmanian Aborigines, and in doing so, to re-establish their pride and identity in contemporary Tasmanian society. These attempts include the production of the first play by and about Tasmanian Aborigines - “We are the Survivors”, by Jim Everett, and the campaign by Aboriginal activist and barrister, Michael Mansell, to reclaim the remains of Tasmanian Aborigines stored in the Anatomy Department of the University of Edinburgh.

results.title: Women: three views
results.creator_credit: Richard Guthrie, Commonwealth Dept of Aboriginal Affairs and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Rainbow serpent”.
Interviews with three Aboriginal women who have chosen to be activists in the struggle for their peoples’ rights. Mum Shirl has been an activist since the late sixties, including initiating the Aboriginal Tent Embassy in the early seventies. Since then she has become disillusioned with political processes in Australia and now chooses to work directly with Aboriginal people in prisons. Marcia Langton works for the Central Lands Council in Alice Springs and she talks passionately on behalf of Aboriginal peoples’ struggles for land rights and dignity. Maryanne Bin-Sallik works within government departments using established political means to argue for the rights of Aborigines. Though choosing very different ways to express their activism, we see that all three women are united in their commitment to work towards an autonomous and central role for Aborigines in Australian politics and culture.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Guthrie, Commonwealth Dept of Aboriginal Affairs and SBS-TV

results.title: A Real man's job: Images of Australian women in wartime [kit]
results.creator_credit: History Teacher's Association of Victoria, Australian War Memorial, ImMEDIAte Action and Felicity Cockram
results.brief_description: Subtitled Images of Australian women in wartime this kit aims to identify the real contribution that women made during both world wars and also at the images of women in wartime that were projected. Authored by Tim Gurry, Robert Lewis and Richard Reid, the kit draws together a wide variety of material with suggestions for its use, into nine Evidence Files, a videocassette and Teacher’s notes.
